item.title: What Makes a Great MAN
item.description: Access to Metropolitan Area Networks (MANs), previously limited to large corporations, is now feasible for small and medium-sized businesses. If your company requires communication between multiple locations within a city, a metro network might be beneficial. Metro Ethernet is the modern solution for data connections in major cities and surrounding areas. There are two main types: E-Line and E-LAN. E-Line provides a direct Ethernet connection between two points, such as a business and its data center, warehouse, factory, or branch office.

item.title: T1, DS3, EoC or Fiber?
item.description: When you require over a Gigabit of bandwidth, fiber is the only option. But what about less demanding situations, needing between 1 Mbps and 100 Mbps? In this range, twisted pair copper, coaxial cable, and fiber optics all become possibilities. So what is the optimal choice today? The Importance of Bandwidth Choice Choosing the right bandwidth connection might seem crucial, but relax. When you opt for dedicated Internet access or point-to-point private lines, performance between options is fairly similar.

item.title: Is 1 Tbps The Next Optical Network Standard?
item.description: While everyday users are getting used to 100 Mbps speeds, network providers are already looking ahead to Terabit per second speeds, debating whether 400 Gbps or 1 Tbps will be the next standard. This push for higher speeds is a natural progression, similar to the advancement from Kbps to Mbps and Gbps. Just like previous upgrades, the proposed standards represent a tenfold increase. This speed increase mirrors Moore’s Law, which predicted the doubling of transistors on integrated circuits yearly.

item.title: What is Ethernet WAN?
item.description: Ethernet WAN is the most significant advancement in business broadband since T1 service prices dropped. What exactly is Ethernet WAN, and why should you care? Ethernet has become the dominant standard for Local Area Networks (LANs). You could say that Ethernet is everywhere. An RJ45 Ethernet jack is standard on every desktop and laptop computer. You might not get a CD-ROM drive, probably won’t get a floppy disc drive, and may never use the phone modem jack again.

item.title: Gigabit to 10 Gigabit to 100 Gigabit WAN
item.description: By: John Shepler As more business operations transition to the cloud and remote work becomes increasingly common, the demand for robust Wide Area Network (WAN) bandwidth has surged. Fortunately, providers offer excellent solutions for establishing high-bandwidth connections between locations and to the internet. Fiber Optic Ethernet WAN Fiber optic connectivity has become the leading choice for business bandwidth. Businesses still relying on older technologies like T1 lines, ISDN PRI, or DS3 bandwidth may be facing limitations and nearing obsolescence.

item.title: E-Rate Discounted Broadband Internet for Schools and Libraries
item.description: Educational institutions and libraries are demanding high-speed internet, which has become essential for business, personal growth, and various types of learning. While most public resources have some internet access, there is increasing pressure to enhance speed for more users and advanced applications. The main obstacle is the cost. Discounted Service is Available A government program offers discounts of 20% to 90% on broadband internet upgrades for most K-12 schools and libraries.

item.title: Ethernet Bandwidth is Downright Cheap
item.description: Business bandwidth solutions are significantly more expensive than residential options like DSL or Cable. While this is partly due to their guaranteed reliability and dedicated lines, another factor is the complex infrastructure involved. Providing business-grade services often requires collaboration between a long-haul carrier and the local phone company for the final connection. Despite recent price drops in dedicated T1 connections, high-bandwidth services remain costly, potentially hindering smaller companies needing to transmit large amounts of data.

item.title: Aggressive Passive Optical Networking
item.description: Passive Optical Networking (PON) is becoming a budget-friendly way to bring fiber optic connections directly to homes and businesses. This technology is advancing so rapidly that new PON standards are being surpassed almost as quickly as they are established. For instance, Ericsson is currently showcasing 10 Gbps GPON. Will we soon see speeds of 100 Gbps or even terabits per second? While it’s not happening overnight, bandwidth requirements are definitely increasing for both home and business wide area networks (WANs).

item.title: When You Need Massive Bandwidth
item.description: By: John Shepler While standard bandwidth offerings from telecom, cable, and fiber providers meet the needs of most businesses, some applications demand exceptionally high bandwidth. This article explores the realm of massive bandwidth options. How Massive Are We Talking? Over the past few decades, WAN bandwidth demands have skyrocketed, mirroring the internet’s growth. We’ve gone from basic T1 lines at 1.5 Mbps to common expectations of 1 Gbps or more. While easily handled by most providers in well-connected areas, limitations arise in rural or underserved locations.

item.title: Gigabit Metro Fiber Ethernet Means Business
item.description: By: John Shepler As data-heavy applications consume more bandwidth, businesses are struggling to keep up. Is there a solution, or are companies destined to lose the bandwidth battle? More Bandwidth to the Rescue Today’s business environment demands more bandwidth than ever before. Older technologies like X.25 and T1 lines are no longer sufficient. Even Ethernet over Copper is just a temporary fix. The optimal solution is connecting to the world through fiber optic bandwidth.

item.title: Gigabit Internet Speed Is Easy to Find
item.description: By: John Shepler Internet bandwidth needs have skyrocketed. While 10 Mbps was once considered high-speed, now even mid-sized offices need around 100 Mbps. For businesses dealing with video production, cloud applications, software delivery, or many users, Gigabit speeds are becoming essential, and thankfully, readily available. #1 Choice: Ethernet over Fiber Fiber optic internet is a future-proof solution. Its infrastructure can handle increasing bandwidth demands, from 1 Gbps to potentially 100 Gbps in the future.

item.title: Lower Cost Last Mile Fiber
item.description: By: John Shepler The Internet’s Most Critical Part: Your Last Mile Connection For internet users like you, especially businesses, the most crucial aspect is the “last mile” connection. This final leg of the network often determines speed and causes the most issues. A better connection is essential, and fiber optic technology is the current gold standard. Last Mile Limitations: Why Fiber Matters It’s important to remember that no internet connection is foolproof.

item.title: 100, 1000, 10000 Mbps Internet Speed
item.description: By: John Shepler As technology progresses, businesses require significantly faster internet speeds. Our Wide Area Networks (WANs) are now crucial for operations. Today, internet connections of 100 Mbps, 1000 Mbps, and even 10,000 Mbps are standard and essential. Fortunately, pricing has decreased as speeds have increased, making these bandwidth levels attainable. 100 Mbps Fast Ethernet 100 Mbps is the current standard bandwidth, replacing the older 45 Mbps DS3 bandwidth. DS3, an upgrade from slower T1 lines, is part of the TDM telecom standard.

item.title: 10 Gbps Dedicated Internet Access Has the Speed You Need
item.description: By John Shepler Gigabit internet speed is like the gold standard for high-speed business connections. But sometimes even 1 Gbps isn’t enough, and that’s when you need to consider upgrading to 10 Gigabit Internet. Who Needs 10 Gbps Bandwidth? Most small businesses and almost all residential internet users don’t need this much speed. The bragging rights aren’t worth the high monthly fees. This level of bandwidth is meant for demanding applications that justify the cost.

item.title: Dell introduces new network switches designed specifically for small businesses
item.description: Dell has improved its networking solutions designed for small and medium-sized businesses (SMBs). Their new X-series smart managed switches and expanded N-series family provide cost-effective, enterprise-grade network control with user-friendly simplicity. The Dell Networking X-Series includes web-managed 1 Gigabit Ethernet (GbE) and 10GbE switches with flexible configuration options. SMBs can benefit from advanced network management without specialized IT staff using step-by-step wizards and customizable dashboards. These features allow for quick and accurate configuration, calibration, and troubleshooting.
